race.name: Paris Mountain Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: South Carolina Paris Mountain gravel in Travelers Rest.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Paris Mountain area. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional SC event. Paris Mountain terrain is nice but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.verdict: Upstate SC Paris Mountain Regional Gravel
biased_opinion.summary: Paris Mountain Gravel Grinder is a regional event in Travelers Rest near Greenville. The Paris Mountain terrain offers significant climbing with mountain scenery, and the proximity to Greenville provides excellent access. However, the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. It's a solid regional event for South Carolina cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional South Carolina gravel race with Paris Mountain terrain. Worth it for SC cyclists seeking a local mountain event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: South Carolina Paris Mountain gravel in Travelers Rest.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in South Carolina and want a local Paris Mountain gravel event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Cohutta, Southern Cross. For similar regional events: other SC gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Travelers Rest and Greenville have lodging options.

course_description.character: Paris Mountain gravel with significant climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Paris Mountain climbing in upstate South Carolina.

non_negotiables.why: Paris Mountain requires solid climbing fitness (5000 feet).
SC spring/fall means heat and humidity are possible.

topics.heat: Racing in SC heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: South Carolina Paris Mountain gravel in Travelers Rest.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with significant climbing near Greenville.

logistics.explanation: Travelers Rest location provides easy highway access from multiple directions, reasonable proximity to Greenville-Spartanburg airport. Small town logistics usually mean simple parking, straightforward packet pickup, none of the urban race chaos.

length.explanation: 65 miles hits the sweet spot for weekend warriors - long enough to matter, short enough to finish before dark. Not the suffer-fest distance that separates pretenders from contenders, but respectable middle ground.

technicality.explanation: Paris Mountain features two distinct climbing approaches - Old Buncome at 2.17 miles and State Park Road at 3.69 miles. The terrain offers "two steep pitches" with grades reaching 10% at the summit and "a few switch backs" on the descent.

elevation.explanation: 5000 feet over 65 miles delivers serious climbing at 77 feet per mile. Paris Mountain alone gains 1,565 feet from Old Buncome side, with the climb averaging "6% but there are only two steep pitches" including a final 10% grade to the summit.

climate.explanation: South Carolina humidity turns any effort into a sweat lodge experience. Summer heat makes racing miserable, winter brings unpredictable ice storms, spring delivers pollen apocalypse.

altitude.explanation: Paris Mountain starts at 1,168 feet on Old Buncome side and tops out at 1,972 feet - minimal altitude with zero physiological impact. You'll get more altitude driving to the race than racing it.

adventure.explanation: The 5.8-mile Paris Mountain traverse offers backcountry feel with safe descending practice. A blogger notes the summit reward: "Aside from a written statement 'You made it' on the top of the climb, there's no view to enjoy."

prestige.explanation: This race barely registers on the gravel radar - no search results, no race reports, no pro field mentions. When a 65-mile grinder in South Carolina can't even get a Wikipedia stub or a single race recap online, you're dealing with pure local theater. The gravel community talks about everything, so radio silence means irrelevance.

race_quality.explanation: Course utilizes quality infrastructure with "recently paved" roads described as "excellent" and "very smooth." However, race organization details and execution standards remain undocumented in available sources.

experience.explanation: 5000 feet of climbing over 65 miles around Travelers Rest suggests you'll get your money's worth of suffering. Paris Mountain State Park terrain means real climbs and actual gravel, not rail-trail nonsense. The experience exists - finding information about it apparently doesn't.

community.explanation: South Carolina gravel scene keeps events intimate and local-focused, which builds tight communities among the dozen people who show up. Travelers Rest sits in cycling-friendly Greenville metro area, so the bones for good community exist. Small fields create bonds - if they create anything at all.

field_depth.explanation: Greenville attracts strong cyclists to Paris Mountain as a go-to training climb (6% average grade, 10% at the top), but the gravel grinder draws from local riders rather than traveling specialists. The Swamp Rabbit Trail cycling corridor near Furman University provides a deep recreational base, though the competitive field stays regional without attracting dedicated gravel racers from outside the Upstate area.

value.explanation: Can't find registration fees, but South Carolina races typically run $60-80 for this distance. 5000 feet of climbing delivers challenge per dollar, assuming the race actually happens. Value depends on execution you can't research in advance.

expenses.explanation: Travelers Rest keeps costs reasonable without Asheville tourist pricing or Atlanta metro expense. Greenville area offers decent lodging options without breaking budgets, supported by established cycling tourism infrastructure.
